Link Mash (February 11, 2014)

Feb 11, 2014
1 minute read

The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Trello. I wish more people knew about this app; it’s completely changed how I manage projects, both professionally and personally. Some of my favorite uses: tracking grocery needs, figuring out Christmas gifts, tracking status on personal projects, and so much more.
  • Zapier. I’ve talked about IFTTT and my love for it before. I recently stumbled upon Zapier, which boasts similar functionality, but with an enormous list of apps. Only downside is that to do heavy lifting with it, you’ll shell out some cash.
  • Turn a Raspberry Pi Into an AirPlay Receiver for Streaming Music in Your Living Room. I recently did this and boy, was it worth it. From my wife: “Babe, AirPi is sooo cool! Thank you so much for making it:)”
  • The Best Resources to Learn to Code. I often get asked how I learned to program; unfortunately, would-be enthusiasts don’t like hearing that I went to college for it. These days, however, resources are limitless and this article highlights a few of my favorites.
  • What if we only bought the stuff we loved? A part of me often feels like I have to buy the things I want right there and now (otherwise, what’s the point?) This article is a great reminder about being more discerning about the things we choose to buy.
  • The Inefficiency of Long Hours. It’s rather arcane for humanity to believe that it needs to work longer and longer to produce results. When it comes to overturning long-held beliefs with data, the Freakonomics guys are the best.
  • Mac Icon Standard. A really neat font that, to use Subtraction’s words, “consists of elegant line drawings of every single model of Macintosh ever shipped.”
Theme crafted with <3 by John Otander (@4lpine).
